Description: The SEC announced settled enforcement actions against seven broker-dealers for failing to disclose they had received payments for providing research coverage of certain public companies, in violation of Section 17(b) of the Securities Act of 1933.

The Securities and Exchange Commission, state regulators, and the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority announced that Morgan Keegan & Company and Morgan Asset Management agreed to pay $200 million to settle fraud charges related to subprime mortgage-backed securities.
The Securities and Exchange Commission announced the settlement of proceedings against 15 broker-dealer firms for engaging in violative practices in the auction rate securities market.
The SEC announced enforcement actions against 36 municipal underwriting firms for violations in municipal bond offerings.
The SEC announced enforcement and disciplinary actions against a total of 15 firms for failure to deliver mutual fund breakpoint discounts during 2001 and 2002.

Company: Raymond James Financial Services Advisors, Inc.

Description: failure to disclose the risks of auction-rate securities

Company: Raymond James & Associates, Inc. et al.
Description: Three Raymond James entities agreed to pay $15 million to settle allegations of improperly charging advisory fees on inactive retail client accounts and charging excess commissions for brokerage customer investments in certain unit investment trusts.

Morgan Keegan agreed to pay an Administrative Assessment of $30,000 and $70,000 in costs in settlement of allegations it failed to exercise reasonable supervision of several of its Agents who were also alleged to have acted with deceit in the sale of securities.

Agency: Connecticut Securities and Business Investments Division

Description: Morgan Keegan agreed to pay $750,000 to the Missouri General Revenue Fund and $100,000 to the Investor Education and Protection Fund in settlement of allegations it failed to adequately investigate and inform investors of the risks of bonds in the Mamtek sucralose factory, which defaulted shortly after the bonds were sold.

Agency: Pennsylvania Department of Banking and Securities
Rhode Island Department of Business Regulation

Description: Raymond James agreed to pay $1,450,00 to the state and $2,750,000 to investors to resolve allegations that it improperly supervised its employees involved in marketing investments under the EB-5 program.

Morgan Keegan agreed to pay $100 million to a group of states as part of a $200 million settlement of litigation alleging it failed to warn investors about the risks of mortgage-backed securities. The larger settlement was announced by the SEC; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-morgan-keegan-and-company
Raymond James agreed to pay $1.75 million to a group of states to resolve allegations the company failed to warn investors about the risks of auction-rate securities.

Company: Raymond James & Associates, Inc. and Raymond James Financial Services, Inc.
Description: Raymond James & Associates, Inc. and Raymond James Financial Services, Inc. agreed to pay a total of approximately $8 million in restitution to customers who incurred excess fees on their investments in 529 savings plans based on the firms' failures to reasonably supervise 529 plan share-class recommendations.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.

Description: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority fined Raymond James Financial Services, Inc. $2 million for failing to maintain reasonably designed supervisory systems and procedures for reviewing email communications.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.

Company: Raymond James & Associates, Inc. and Raymond James Financial Services, Inc.
Description: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority fined Raymond James & Associates, Inc. (RJA) and Raymond James Financial Services, Inc. (RJFS), a total of $17 million for widespread failures related to the firms' anti-money laundering (AML) programs. RJA was fined $8 million and RJFS was fined $9 million for failing to establish and implement adequate AML procedures, which resulted in the firms' failure to properly prevent or detect, investigate, and report suspicious activity for several years.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.

Company: Raymond James & Associates, Inc. and Raymond James Financial Services, Inc.
Description: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority ordered Wells Fargo Advisors, LLC, Wells Fargo Advisors Financial Network, LLC, Raymond James & Associates, Inc., Raymond James Financial Services, Inc. and LPL Financial LLC to pay more than $30 million in restitution, including interest, to affected customers for failing to waive mutual fund sales charges for certain charitable and retirement accounts. Wells Fargo, Raymond James and LPL were required to pay affected customers an estimated $15 million, $8.7 million and $6.3 million, respectively.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.

Company: Raymond James & Associates, Inc. and Raymond James Financial Services, Inc.
Description: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority ordered Raymond James & Associates, Inc. (RJA) and Raymond James Financial Services, Inc. (RJFS) to pay restitution of $1.69 million to more than 15,500 investors who were charged unfair and unreasonable commissions on securities transactions. FINRA also fined RJA $225,000 and RJFS $200,000.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.

Description: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority imposed a fine of $1 million against Raymond James & Associates, Inc. of St. Petersburg, FL, and a fine of $400,000 against RBC Capital Markets Corporation of New York, for various stock loan improprieties.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.

Description: NASD fined Raymond James Financial Services, Inc. $2.75 million for failing to maintain an adequate supervisory system to oversee the sales activities of over 1,000 producing branch managers working in offices throughout the United States.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).

Description: NASD censured and fined 20 securities firms a total of $1.65 million for late and/or inaccurate reporting of tens of thousands of municipal securities transactions to the Municipal Securities Rulemaking Board.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).

Company: Raymond James & Associates, Inc. and Raymond James Financial Services, Inc.
Description: NASD censured and fined Raymond James & Associates, Inc. and Raymond James Financial Services, Inc. $750,000 for violations relating to the firms' fee-based brokerage business.  The firms were also required to pay restitution totaling  $138,000.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).

Description: NASD censured and fined 29 securities firms over $9.2 million for more than 8,000 late disclosures of reportable information about their brokers, including customer complaints, regulatory actions, and criminal charges and convictions.
Info Source: NASD Fines 29 Firms over $9.2 Million for Late Reporting, PR Newswire, November 30, 2004 (via Nexis).
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).

Description: NASD Regulation, Inc. censured seven brokerage firms for engaging in the practice of yield burning and ordered them to pay a total of $21.4 million to the U.S. Treasury, under an agreement with the Internal Revenue Service and the United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York, and to pay disgorgement directly to 38 municipal issuers. The NASD press release did not specify how much each firm would pay. That information was obtained from an April 7, 2000 Associated Press article retrieved via Nexis.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).
